rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 16–31
rsbNotes.text: 16:1–31:13 These chapters narrate David’s rise to power and Saul’s fall from power and his death. David’s rise is marked by his anointing by Samuel and his time in Saul’s service (chs. 16–18), his flight from Saul (chs. 19–23), his avoidance of bloodguilt (chs. 24–26), and his escape to the Philistines (chs. 27–31).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 18:5
rsbNotes.text: 18:5 Saul set him over the men of war. Military success continues to be David’s hallmark, and Saul gives David a rank in the army commensurate with his accomplishments.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 18:7
rsbNotes.text: 18:7 David his ten thousands. See 21:11; 29:5. It is a common feature of Hebrew poetry for one or more terms in the first half of a verse to be increased or intensified in the second half. For the thousand-ten thousand parallelism, see Deut. 32:30; Ps. 91:7; 144:13; Mic. 6:7. Whether the women’s song praises Saul and David as equals or implies that David is better than Saul, Saul certainly takes offense to it (v. 8).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 18:8
rsbNotes.text: 18:8 what more can he have but the kingdom. Saul rightly senses that David may be the “neighbor” who will replace him (15:28; 17:55 note).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 18:10
rsbNotes.text:
18:10 a harmful spirit. See note 16:14.

raved. Ecstatic experiences could be caused by God’s Spirit (10:6, 15), but also by evil spirits or false prophets (1 Kin. 18:29).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 18:12
rsbNotes.text:
18:12 the Lord was with him. See 16:18 and note.

had departed from Saul. See 16:14 and note.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 18:13–16
rsbNotes.text: 18:13–16 Saul’s removal of David from the court, with an accompanying demotion in military rank, may be intended to decrease David’s visibility and popularity, as well as to increase the risk of his dying in battle. The effect of Saul’s scheming, however, is actually the reverse. David is brought into closer contact with the people, so that “all Israel and Judah loved David” (v. 16).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 18:17–19
rsbNotes.text: 18:17–19 In view of David’s great popularity, Saul cannot continue to delay fulfilling his promise (17:25). Nevertheless, he adds a further condition, that David “fight the Lord’s battles,” in the hope that the Philistines would kill David for him (vv. 17, 21, 25). David says that he lacks the social standing to marry the king’s daughter, a conventional protest in such circumstances (cf. 9:21). At the last minute, Saul reneges on his promise and gives Merab to someone else.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 18:20–27
rsbNotes.text: 18:20–27 When Saul’s second daughter Michal falls in love with David, Saul offers David another chance to become his son-in-law (vv. 20, 21). He adds again to the conditions David must fulfill (v. 25). David wastes no time (v. 26) in meeting Saul’s requirement twice over, and becomes the king’s son-in-law (v. 27).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 18:28–29
rsbNotes.text: 18:28, 29 the Lord was with David. Saul’s increasing fear of David is well-founded, since the Lord is with David (vv. 12, 14). David’s success would not have distressed Saul so much if, like Jonathan, Saul had been able to accept his rejection with equanimity.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:1
rsbNotes.text: 19:1 they should kill David. Saul’s covert attempts on David’s life having come to nothing (ch. 18), he decides to take a direct approach.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:4
rsbNotes.text: 19:4 Jonathan spoke well of David. Jonathan’s magnanimity towards David stands in stark contrast to Saul’s malevolence, continuing the unfavorable comparison of father and son noted earlier (13:22; 14:1, 6, 10, 29 and notes). It seems likely that Jonathan’s loyalty to David stems not from ignorance of David’s destiny, but from a willing acceptance of it (18:4 note; 23:17 note).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:9
rsbNotes.text: 19:9 a harmful spirit. See note 16:14.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:10
rsbNotes.text: 19:10 Saul sought to pin David to the wall. Perhaps again galled by David’s military success (v. 8; 18:8), Saul resorts to one of his old tricks (18:10, 11).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:11
rsbNotes.text: 19:11 Michal, David’s wife, told him. As Saul’s designs on David’s life become increasingly intense and overt, David is warned first by Saul’s son (v. 2) and then by his daughter.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:12
rsbNotes.text: 19:12 he fled away and escaped. Henceforth, David will be on the run from Saul.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:13
rsbNotes.text: 19:13 an image. The Hebrew same term is translated “household gods” in Gen. 31:19, 34, 35; Judg. 18:14. The Genesis references imply small objects, while the present reference suggests something larger.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:17
rsbNotes.text: 19:17 He said to me. Michal’s deception here has an element of self-preservation. In light of Saul’s later behavior (20:32, 33), Michal had reason to be afraid of him (cf. 16:2).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:18
rsbNotes.text:
19:18 Ramah. See note 1:1.

Naioth. This word, which occurs only in this section, is associated with the place name Ramah. It is quite possibly not a proper noun at all, but a word meaning the “camps” in which the prophets at Ramah were active (compare the prophets’ lodge in 2 Kin. 6:1, 2).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:20
rsbNotes.text: 19:20 the company of the prophets prophesying. See note 10:5.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:22
rsbNotes.text: 19:22 great well . . . in Secu. Secu is unknown, but it may be a site about two miles north of Ramah. Some have suggested reconstructing the difficult Hebrew on the basis of Septuagint (the Old Testament Greek translation) to read “well of the threshing floor on the bare height.” This could have been a familiar landmark, such as are mentioned more than once in Samuel (20:19; 2 Sam. 20:8).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:23
rsbNotes.text: 19:23 the Spirit of God came upon him. Having set out to destroy David, Saul has been frustrated by Jonathan, Michal, Samuel, and now finally by God Himself.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 19:24
rsbNotes.text: 19:24 he too stripped off his clothes. Robes in the books of Samuel often seem to have a symbolic significance, frequently pertaining to the kingship (15:28; 18:4; 24:4–6 and notes). While Jonathan’s gift of his robe to David in 18:4 was voluntary, Saul’s action here is under the compulsion of God’s Spirit.
